diagrams.description: Data Science emerged from statistics, computer science, and domain-specific analysis convergence. Early statistical methods developed in the 1600s-1800s provided mathematical foundations. The term data science appeared in the 1960s describing work with data. Relational databases (1970s) enabled structured data storage and SQL querying. Statistical software like SAS (1976) and SPSS facilitated analysis. The data warehousing concept emerged in the 1980s for business intelligence. The World Wide Web (1990s) generated massive data volumes requiring new approaches. The term data mining gained popularity in the 1990s for pattern discovery. Big Data became prominent around 2005 with web-scale data challenges. Hadoop (2006) provided distributed processing framework. The Data Scientist role gained recognition through DJ Patil and Jeff Hammerbacher (2008) at LinkedIn and Facebook. Machine learning libraries like scikit-learn (2007) democratized advanced analytics. Cloud computing platforms (2010s) provided scalable infrastructure. Deep learning breakthroughs (2012+) expanded analytical capabilities. Today's data science integrates AutoML, MLOps, real-time analytics, and responsible AI practices.

timeline
    title The History of Data Science
    section The Foundations
        1962 : John Tukey - "The Future of Data Analysis"
        1977 : Peter Naur - "Concise Survey of Computer Methods"
    section The 1980s & 1990s: Databases and Data Mining
        1980s : Relational databases become standard
        1990s : KDD (Knowledge Discovery in Databases) & Data Mining emerge
        1997 : C.F. Jeff Wu - "Statistics = Data Science?"
    section The 2000s: The Rise of Big Data
        2001 : William S. Cleveland - "Data Science: An Action Plan for Expanding the Technical Areas of the Field of Statistics"
        2008 : The term "Data Scientist" is coined (DJ Patil & Jeff Hammerbacher)
        2009 : Hadoop and MapReduce become popular
    section The 2010s: The Age of the Data Scientist
        2010s : Rise of Python & R for data science
        2012 : Harvard Business Review calls Data Scientist the "Sexiest Job of the 21st Century"
        2015 : TensorFlow is released
